content: I’m about to buy a tablet to run OpenCPN. That creates a choice between an Android tablet and a Windows tablet. Any advice on which runs OpenCPN and its plugins more reliably? All other things being equal I’d favor Android, but not if OpenCPN on Android is less reliable/usable than on Windows. Any advice much appreciated.
I purchased a Sailproof tablet last summer. I see no major problems and the hardware is really nice, good enough to use outdoors
Thanks! You’re the second person who’s recommended the Sailproof. :+1:

By the way, I just tried accessing OpenCPN remotely using VNC over WiFi from my iPad and it really doesn’t work very well (somewhat unsurprisingly). It’s very laggy, and the UI very clunky to use (partly due to the lag). Just in case anyone’s considering that as an alternative.

Thanks, I’ll try them all, just for the record.

But I would expect none of them to work very well with accelerated graphics like satellite images using OpenGL, which is a very common use case (getting good satellite images to the helm). I think most of the Remote Desktop protocols are probably optimized for traditional applications displaying text, widgets and vectors.
Using a cable it's fine running against my Orange Pi 5, networked it's barely usable
... and I dont use satellite images.
what kind of cable are you referring to?
Also, now that ive figured out how the UI works over vnc, its not as terrible as it was initially.

The trick is to setup something, I have an RPi, which is connected to the sensors and then feeds the tablet with NMEA data over UDP. This works great, the display is local. You just need to replicate routes and such.
cable: Forget it, it's when using a laptop
